passages.text: Poor 2Q results, but does really matter?

SJM's 2Q results came in significantly below expectations on very weak margins, dragged by poor VIP luck and higher- than- expected OPEX. That said, the cut in forward EBITDA isn't that big at about \(- 4\%\) as the downside is partially offset by better- than- expected industry demand momentum ("a rising tide lifts all boats", even the worst ones). We think the impact on the stock - beyond the obvious kneejerk reaction - may not be very significant (and should have minimal read across to its peers, as SJM was the last one to report 2Q). Thus, we maintain our Neutral rating despite our bullish view on the sector (recall, we rate all other operators at OW), keeping it at the bottom of our pecking order. Our price target of \(\mathrm{HK}\) 2.8 (was \(\mathrm{HK}\) 3.0) is based on SOTP, suggesting c. \(15\%\) potential downside from here.

- 2Q25 in a nutshell. SJM's EBITDA fell \(28\%\) q/q to \(\mathrm{HK}\) 688m, coming in well below even the lowest estimate on the Street (which was actually JPME at HK \(798\mathrm{m}\) vs. consensus of \(\mathrm{HK}\) 916m). There was a significant drag from VIP luck (-HK\)114m), but even its luck-adjusted EBITDA of \(\mathrm{HK}\) 802m was still \(13\%\) below Street consensus (albeit in-line with JPME) and implies a \(17\%\) decline q/q. This is in stark contrast to all of its peers, who had their EBITDA growing \(+6\%\) q/q on average in 2Q.

- 2Q25 details. SJM was the largest market share donor in 2Q as expected, losing 120bps q/q to \(12.3\%\) , due to share loss in mass/slot (-100bps q/q to \(13.4\%\) ) and to a lesser extent unfavorable VIP luck. The downside in EBITDA came primarily from its poor margins (9.6%, vs. 12.8% in 1Q25), dragged by its flagship GLP which turned into EBITDA losses. GLP's OPEX kept rising (HK \(8.6\mathrm{m / day}\) , \(+5\%\) q/q and \(+23\%\) y/y) and even its VIP luck-adjusted EBITDA declined \(>50\%\) q/q to only \(+HK\) 48m (vs. \(+HK\) 109m in 1Q) amidst its share loss (2.2%, vs. 2.4% in 1Q). See Table 1-3 for a detailed summary of the results.

- No updates on satellite transactions. Management said it is still in negotiations with two satellite casino owners (L'arC and Ponte 16) for a potential acquisition, with no comment on pricing or timing (except that the transaction, if it were to happen, should be finalized by year-end according to the regulations). Separately, SJM announced (see link) that it will expand the gaming floor of the Lisboa Casino (the original Lisboa that opened 55 years ago) to accommodate more tables from satellite casinos after the shut-down, and it will pay \(\mathrm{HK}\) 579m to its parent-co STDM to get the additional space (recall, Hotel Lisboa property itself is owned by STDM, except for the gaming floor which is under SJM via a concession contract).

- Thoughts on its balance sheet. SJM's balance sheet does not show any sign of improvement either, as its net debt kept edging up to \(\mathrm{HK}\) 23.9B (+HK\)0.4B q/q), which is bigger than its current market cap and implies a nearly 7x net leverage ratio (= net debt / TTM EBITDA), by far the highest level in Macau. However, management was very clear during the call that it will not consider any equity raise, as it plans to utilize more bank loans to refinance its bonds and fund the aforementioned transactions, if needed.
Sources for: Style Exposure - J.P. Morgan Global Markets Strategy; all other tables are company data and J.P. Morgan estimates.

SJM remains our only Neutral among the six Macau operators, as we struggle to see how the stock meaningfully outperforms its peers in Macau at this juncture. Despite SJM's stable market share last year, peers' new offerings - such as Sands' Londoner Grand and Galaxy's Capella - could erode its market share into 2H25E and FY26E, dragging on its EBITDA delivery. Moreover, SJM trades higher than most of its peers on EV/EBITDA or P/E, based on JPME. There is no support from cash returns either (we don't think it can pay any dividend in the next two years given its stretched balance sheet), and we remain Neutral despite our bullish stance on the sector.

Our Dec- 26 PT of HK\$2.8 is based on a property- by- property sum- of- the- parts valuation that implies a 9x FY25E EV/EBITDA, compared to its historical mid- cycle multiple range of 11- 12x. We view the multiple as fair compared to what we assume for its peers (9- 12x).

SJM remains our only Neutral among the six Macau operators, as we struggle to see how the stock meaningfully outperforms its peers in Macau at this juncture. Despite SJM's stable market share last year, peers' new offerings - such as Sands' Londoner Grand and Galaxy's Capella - could erode its market share into 2H25E and FY26E, dragging on its EBITDA delivery. Moreover, SJM trades higher than most of its peers on EV/EBITDA or P/E, based on JPM. There is no support from cash returns either (we don't think it can pay any dividend in the next two years given its stretched balance sheet), and we remain Neutral despite our bullish stance on the sector.

Our Dec- 26 PT of HK\$2.8 is based on a property- by- property sum- of- the- parts valuation that implies a 9x FY25E EV/EBITDA, compared to its historical mid- cycle multiple range of 11- 12x. We view the multiple as fair compared to what we assume for its peers (9- 12x).
